sp.l: O mistress, villany hath made mocks with love,
My husband say that she was false!

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: He, woman;
I say thy husband: dost understand the word?
My friend, thy husband, honest, honest Iago.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: If he say so, may his pernicious soul
Rot half a grain a day! he lies to the heart:
She was too fond of her most filthy bargain.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: Do thy worst:
This deed of thine is no more worthy heaven
Than thou wast worthy her.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Peace, you were best.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: Thou hast not half that power to do me harm
As I have to be hurt. O gull! O dolt!
As ignorant as dirt! thou hast done a deed--
I care not for thy sword; I'll make thee known,
Though I lost twenty lives.--Help! help, ho! help!
The Moor hath kill'd my mistress! Murder! murder!

div.stage: Enter Montano, Gratiano, Iago, and others

sp.speaker: Montano
sp.l: What is the matter? How now, general!

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: O, are you come, Iago? you have done well,
That men must lay their murders on your neck.

sp.speaker: Gratiano
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: Disprove this villain, if thou be'st a man:
He says thou told'st him that his wife was false:
I know thou didst not, thou'rt not such a villain:
Speak, for my heart is full.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: I told him what I thought, and told no more
Than what he found himself was apt and true.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: But did you ever tell him she was false?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: I did.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: You told a lie, an odious, damned lie;
Upon my soul, a lie, a wicked lie.
She false with Cassio!--did you say with Cassio?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: With Cassio, mistress. Go to, charm your tongue.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: I will not charm my tongue; I am bound to speak:
My mistress here lies murder'd in her bed,--

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: O heavens forfend!

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: And your reports have set the murder on.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Nay, stare not, masters: it is true, indeed.

sp.speaker: Gratiano
sp.l: 'Tis a strange truth.

sp.speaker: Montano
sp.l: O monstrous act!

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: Villany, villany, villany!
I think upon't, I think: I smell't: O villany!--
I thought so then:--I'll kill myself for grief:--
O villany, villany!

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: What, are you mad? I charge you, get you home.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: Good gentlemen, let me have leave to speak:
'Tis proper I obey him, but not now.
Perchance, Iago, I will ne'er go home.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: O! O! O!

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: Nay, lay thee down and roar;
For thou hast kill'd the sweetest innocent
That e'er did lift up eye.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Rising O, she was foul!
I scarce did know you, uncle: there lies your niece,
Whose breath, indeed, these hands have newly stopp'd:
I know this act shows horrible and grim.

sp.speaker: Gratiano
sp.l: Poor Desdemona! I am glad thy father's dead:
Thy match was mortal to him, and pure grief
Shore his old thread in twain: did he live now,
This sight would make him do a desperate turn,
Yea, curse his better angel from his side,
And fall to reprobation.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: 'Tis pitiful; but yet Iago knows
That she with Cassio hath the act of shame
A thousand times committed; Cassio confess'd it:
And she did gratify his amorous works
With that recognizance and pledge of love
Which I first gave her; I saw it in his hand:
It was a handkerchief, an antique token
My father gave my mother.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: O heaven! O heavenly powers!

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Come, hold your peace.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: 'Twill out, 'twill out: I peace!
No, I will speak as liberal as the north:
Let heaven and men and devils, let them all,
All, all, cry shame against me, yet I'll speak.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Be wise, and get you home.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: I will not.

sp.speaker: Gratiano
sp.l: Fie!
Your sword upon a woman?

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: O thou dull Moor! that handkerchief thou speak'st of
I found by fortune and did give my husband;
For often, with a solemn earnestness,
More than indeed belong'd to such a trifle,
He begg'd of me to steal it.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Villanous whore!

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: She give it Cassio! no, alas! I found it,
And I did give't my husband.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Filth, thou liest!

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: By heaven, I do not, I do not, gentlemen.
O murderous coxcomb! what should such a fool
Do with so good a woman?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Are there no stones in heaven
But what serve for the thunder?--Precious villain!

div.stage: He runs at Iago Iago, from behind, stabs Emilia, and exit

sp.speaker: Gratiano
sp.l: The woman falls; sure, he hath kill'd his wife.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: Ay, ay: O, lay me by my mistress' side.

sp.speaker: Gratiano
sp.l: He's gone, but his wife's kill'd.

sp.speaker: Montano
sp.l: 'Tis a notorious villain. Take you this weapon,
Which I have here recover'd from the Moor:
Come, guard the door without; let him not pass,
But kill him rather. I'll after that same villain,
For 'tis a damned slave.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: I am not valiant neither,
But ever puny whipster gets my sword:
But why should honour outlive honesty?
Let it go all.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: What did thy song bode, lady?
Hark, canst thou hear me? I will play the swan.
And die in music.
Willow, willow, willow,--
Moor, she was chaste; she loved thee, cruel Moor;
So come my soul to bliss, as I speak true;
So speaking as I think, I die, I die.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: I have another weapon in this chamber;
It is a sword of Spain, the ice-brook's temper:--
O, here it is. Uncle, I must come forth.

sp.speaker: Gratiano
sp.l: Within If thou attempt it, it will cost thee dear:
Thou hast no weapon, and perforce must suffer.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Look in upon me then and speak with me,
Or, naked as I am, I will assault thee.

sp.speaker: Gratiano
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Behold, I have a weapon;
A better never did itself sustain
Upon a soldier's thigh: I have seen the day,
That, with this little arm and this good sword,
I have made my way through more impediments
Than twenty times your stop: but, O vain boast!
Who can control his fate? 'tis not so now.
Be not afraid, though you do see me weapon'd;
Here is my journey's end, here is my butt,
And very sea-mark of my utmost sail.
Do you go back dismay'd? 'tis a lost fear;
Man but a rush against Othello's breast,
And he retires. Where should Othello go?
Now, how dost thou look now? O ill-starr'd wench!
Pale as thy smock! when we shall meet at compt,
This look of thine will hurl my soul from heaven,
And fiends will snatch at it. Cold, cold, my girl!
Even like thy chastity. O cursed slave!
Whip me, ye devils,
From the possession of this heavenly sight!
Blow me about in winds! roast me in sulphur!
Wash me in steep-down gulfs of liquid fire!
O Desdemona! Desdemona! dead!
Oh! Oh! Oh!

div.stage: Enter Lodovico. Montano, Cassio carried in a chair, and Officers with Iago, prisoner

sp.speaker: Lodovico
sp.l: Where is this rash and most unfortunate man?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: That's he that was Othello: here I am.

sp.speaker: Lodovico
sp.l: Where is that viper? bring the villain forth.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: I look down towards his feet; but that's a fable.
If that thou best a devil, I cannot kill thee.

sp.speaker: Lodovico
sp.l: Wrench his sword from him.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: I bleed, sir; but not kill'd.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: I am not sorry neither: I'ld have thee live;
For, in my sense, 'tis happiness to die.

sp.speaker: Lodovico
sp.l: O thou Othello, thou wert once so good,
Fall'n in the practise of a damned slave,
What shall be said to thee?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Why, any thing:
An honourable murderer, if you will;
For nought I did in hate, but all in honour.

sp.speaker: Lodovico
sp.l: This wretch hath part confess'd his villany:
Did you and he consent in Cassio's death?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Ay.

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.l: Dear general, I never gave you cause.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: I do believe it, and I ask your pardon.
Will you, I pray, demand that demi-devil
Why he hath thus ensnared my soul and body?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Demand me nothing: what you know, you know:
From this time forth I never will speak word.

sp.speaker: Lodovico
sp.l: What, not to pray?

sp.speaker: Gratiano
sp.l: Torments will ope your lips.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Well, thou dost best.

sp.speaker: Lodovico
sp.l: Sir, you shall understand what hath befall'n,
Which, as I think, you know not. Here is a letter
Found in the pocket of the slain Roderigo;
And here another: the one of them imports
The death of Cassio to be undertook
By Roderigo.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: O villain!

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.l: Most heathenish and most gross!

sp.speaker: Lodovico
sp.l: Now here's another discontented paper,
Found in his pocket too; and this, it seems,
Roderigo meant to have sent this damned villain;
But that belike Iago in the interim
Came in and satisfied him.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: O the pernicious caitiff!
How came you, Cassio, by that handkerchief
That was my wife's?

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.l: I found it in my chamber:
And he himself confess'd but even now
That there he dropp'd it for a special purpose
Which wrought to his desire.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: O fool! fool! fool!

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.l: There is besides in Roderigo's letter,
How he upbraids Iago, that he made him
Brave me upon the watch; whereon it came
That I was cast: and even but now he spake,
After long seeming dead, Iago hurt him,
Iago set him on.

sp.speaker: Lodovico
sp.l: You must forsake this room, and go with us:
Your power and your command is taken off,
And Cassio rules in Cyprus. For this slave,
If there be any cunning cruelty
That can torment him much and hold him long,
It shall be his. You shall close prisoner rest,
Till that the nature of your fault be known
To the Venetian state. Come, bring him away.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Soft you; a word or two before you go.
I have done the state some service, and they know't.
No more of that. I pray you, in your letters,
When you shall these unlucky deeds relate,
Speak of me as I am; nothing extenuate,
Nor set down aught in malice: then must you speak
Of one that loved not wisely but too well;
Of one not easily jealous, but being wrought
Perplex'd in the extreme; of one whose hand,
Like the base Indian, threw a pearl away
Richer than all his tribe; of one whose subdued eyes,
Albeit unused to the melting mood,
Drop tears as fast as the Arabian trees
Their medicinal gum. Set you down this;
And say besides, that in Aleppo once,
Where a malignant and a turban'd Turk
Beat a Venetian and traduced the state,
I took by the throat the circumcised dog,
And smote him, thus.

sp.speaker: Lodovico
sp.l: O bloody period!

sp.speaker: Gratiano
sp.l: All that's spoke is marr'd.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: I kiss'd thee ere I kill'd thee: no way but this;
Killing myself, to die upon a kiss.

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.l: This did I fear, but thought he had no weapon;
For he was great of heart.

sp.speaker: Lodovico
sp.l: To Iago O Spartan dog,
More fell than anguish, hunger, or the sea!
Look on the tragic loading of this bed;
This is thy work: the object poisons sight;
Let it be hid. Gratiano, keep the house,
And seize upon the fortunes of the Moor,
For they succeed on you. To you, lord governor,
Remains the censure of this hellish villain;
The time, the place, the torture: O, enforce it!
Myself will straight aboard: and to the state
This heavy act with heavy heart relate.
